Tsendsuren Munkhdalai

Currently I am a postdoctoral associate at Prof. Hong’s BioNLP group at UMass. I recently graduated from the Department of Computer Science at Chungbuk National University, South Korea under the excellent supervision of Prof. Keun Ho Ryu.

My research focuses on semi-supervised learning, representation learning and deep learning for natural language understanding and clinical/biomedical information extraction.

I have several years of experience in programming with java (EE), including swing, JSF, EJB, and JPA. In addition, I have recently been playing with Scala, Python, R and Lua. I got the opportunity to try deep learning frameworks like Torch, Chainer, MXNET and Keras, data processing tools like Mahout, Scikit-learn, Weka and Opencv (Javacv), NoSQL database systems including Hbase, Redis, MongoDB and Cassandra, indexing technologies such as Apache Solr and Lucene, distributed computing and storage tools like Hadoop, Spark and Scalding (for Hadoop) and some other systems for document processing pipelines.

I would like to do a few sport activities frequently: bodybuilding, soccer, volleyball and swimming. I also like to have a beer while playing pool and discussing ideas and technology.

News

  • Our paper on reasoning with memory augmented neural networks is accepted at ICLR 2017!
  • I am giving a talk at the MLFL on 2/14 [slides].
  • Our two long paper submissions (Neural Tree Indexers and Neural Semantic Encoders) are accepted at EACL 2017!
  • We arxived our new paper, Reasoning with Memory Augmented Neural Networks for Language Comprehension [link|code will be available].
  • We opensourced the implementation of our Full tree matching NTI-SLSTM-LSTM model, which obtains 87.3% accuracy on Stanford NLI dataset.
  • Our paper on citation analysis with neural attention models (pdf) is accepted for EMNLP 2016 LOUHI workshop.
  • We published our two recent work on arxiv.
    • Neural Semantic Encoders [link|code will be available]
    • Neural Tree Indexers for Text Understanding [link|code]
  • My dissertation is available: Domain Knowledge-rich Biomedical Information Extraction Methods based on Deep Neural Networks.
  • I got the chance to attend Deep Learning Summer School 2015 in Montreal. There I presented our poster: DeepText: End-to-end biomedical event extraction via deep learning and recursive projection model

Open source software

  • DeepText: An end-to-end biomedical event extraction system based on deep learning and recursive projection model, written in Scala and Lua (using Torch).
  • BANNER-CHEMDNER: A multi-domain named entity recognition system that can be used to identify chemical and drug mention, biomedical mention or disease mention from text, written in Java.
